Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel family of cellulose acetate fluorescent nanoparticles for bio imaging applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cellulose is one of the most abundant biocompatible materials on earth. Cellulose acetate, viscose, or artificial silk are the most technologically developed and well-characterized derivatives of cellulose, which is completely benign to humans. While various optical materials have been developed from cellulose acetate (CA), optical nanomaterials made of this cellulose derivative are nonexistent. This proposal deals with the development of the first fluorescent nanoparticles and nanofibers made of cellulose acetate (CA), that would make them potentially transformative for biomedical applications.

The project will study CA nano-optical properties then evaluate their potential as labels and sensors for biophotonic applications. Initial work demonstrated the presence of donor-acceptor coupling between encapsulated dyes. Encapsulating hydrophobic fluorescent dyes have many advantages such as exceptional photostability. These features suggest the potential of a new platform for developing a whole family of fluorescent nanoparticles and nanosensors for biomedical applications. There is a clear need to address key exploratory questions to reduce the high risk of this transformative approach. For example, photonic properties of encapsulated dyes inside of CA nanoparticles has not been studied. The role of fluorescent and functional molecules in the particle synthesis is unclear. These questions and others will be addressed in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Second life of cellulose acetate: advance in biophotonics 

 

By controlling molecular forces in nanoprecipitation processes, a team of scientists has demonstrated the development of a family of unique ultrabright fluorescent nanoparticles (CA-dots) made of cellulose acetate, a human benign material. The particles seem to be capable of precise targeting of tumors, whereas ultrabright fluorescence allows visualizing even very small cancer lesions.

Benign nature and the expected negligible cost of CA-dots make them potentially transformative for various biomedical applications, including previously unfeasible due to the high cost and toxicity concerns, for example, topical applications of CA-dots during colonoscopy, intravenous injections for monitoring cancer lesions. CA-dots can also be used for general biomedical imaging.

Cellulose acetate (viscose, or artificial silk) is a biocompatible human-benign derivative of cellulose, one of the most abundant biopolymers on earth. While various optical materials have been developed using this material, optical cellulose acetate nanomaterials were nonexistent. With the help of this exploratory grant from NSF, the researchers have demonstrated the feasibility to develop a whole new family of very bright fluorescent nanoparticles made of this material, which can be functionalized with various targeting molecules. CA-dots of four different colors, blue, green, yellow and near-infrared were demonstrated. Compared to the standard bright fluorescent nanoparticles (quantum dots) of similar color, the developed nanoparticles are 40-1300 times brighter. This makes the detection of these particles easier and faster.

In collaboration with Boston University and MIT, the researchers at Tufts University have demonstrated a surprisingly good ability of CA dots to target epithelial tumors. Examples of targeting colorectal cancer in mice and human cervical cancer implanted in zebrafish were presented.

Cellulose acetate is cheap, high purity, available in industrial quantities. This makes CA-dots potentially translational to clinical applications. For example, topical applications of fluorescent taggants (fluorophores) are promising for early detection of colon, cervical, oral cancers. At present, it is cost-prohibitive even for the developed countries due to a high cost of targeting fluorophores. CA nanoparticles can make this approach clinically feasible.
